Are you referring to Yubikeys and similar devices or a specific passwordless implementation?
Signal supporting it for registration lock and PIN would be amazing!

posts.name: ðŸ‘ŠðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ðŸ”¥
posts.cooked: Not security/hardware keys, but passkeys.

link_counts.title: What are passkeys? Everything you need to know about the death of passwords | Tom's Guide

posts.cooked: They are somewhat related. The passkey standard that you linked can be used on many types of devices including phones and Yubikeys. Every Yubikey currently offered supports that type of passkey storage.

posts.name: ðŸ‘ŠðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ðŸ”¥
posts.cooked: Oh cool. Didnâ€™t realize passkeys could be put on Yubikeys. My intention when passkeys become more prevalent is for my Yubikeys to become a backup if something happens to my phone.

That is close to how I use them. I donâ€™t use them for passwordless yet, just for multifactor authentication.

How are you using your Yubikeys now? The FIDO or WebAuthN features are passkeys and are the same type that are stored on a phone that supports them.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Doesnâ€™t using passkeys with a Yubikey kind of defeats the purpose?
The idea is to have something you know (your phoneâ€™s passcode) plus something you have (the phone itself). Storing a passkey on a hardware key reduces it back to one factor.

Either way, my thinking is as follows: passkeys are awesome for the general public, because you pretty much force 2FA at people without them even noticing. I still, however, think a randomised password + a FIDO key is more secure, as those have the benefit of being non-phishable anyway.

posts.name: ðŸ‘ŠðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ðŸ”¥
posts.cooked:
I read Yubicoâ€™s blog on Passkeys. I didnâ€™t realize they were basically just a re-brand of FIDO keys for the general public .

Right now I have FIDO Yubikeys set up wherever itâ€™s supported. If itâ€™s not then I fall back to app 2FA via codes stored on my Yubikey and generated by Yubico Authenticator. And then of course SMS 2FA for accounts that donâ€™t support anything better.

Iâ€™m eventually going to run into a problem with the app 2FA bit because Yubikeys only store app 2FA secrets for something like 30 or 32 accounts and Iâ€™m very close to that on both keys (with some duplication between both because one is USB-A and the other is USB-C). Iâ€™m hoping Passkeys get a quicker uptake than app 2FA and FIDO keys have so I can upgrade all my accounts off of SMS 2FA.

I really like the idea of passkeys and am hoping that they become mainstream sooner than later.

Personally I self host a password manager that stores both my password and totp.
Yes thatâ€™s not the point of 2FA but to access this account I use my master password and the yubikey making my passwords and TOTP codes secured by multiple factors.

Iâ€™ve also setup webauthn wherever possible and only have the TOTP as a backup over there (havenâ€™t had to use it yet but once I need Iâ€™ll really pay attention).
All important accounts do support webauthn so thatâ€™s a big plus.

Once passkeys are a thing Iâ€™ll probably continue with this (save them in my password manager thatâ€™s secured by multiple factors). This basically enables having secure passwords in places that limit your choices (some providers limit special characters or even have a character limit).

Also before someone calls my strategy bs: I know that it somehow defeats he use of 2FA but even if I used a different app for TOTP and my passwords Iâ€™d probably still unlock them both with my fingerprint (out of convenience).

posts.name: ðŸ‘ŠðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ðŸ”¥
posts.cooked:
Leptopoda:

Iâ€™d probably still unlock them both with my fingerprint (out of convenience).

I access my passwords nearly exclusively from my phone and I donâ€™t have time to type my tens of characters master password whenever I need to access them, so I also use biometrics with my password manager.

Biometrics for convenience is not BS, and anyone claiming so is probably a hypocrite.

Talya (she/her):

Doesnâ€™t using passkeys with a Yubikey kind of defeats the purpose?
The idea is to have something you know (your phoneâ€™s passcode) plus something you have (the phone itself). Storing a passkey on a hardware key reduces it back to one factor.

All current Yubikeys have the ability to add an alphanumeric PIN to protect the FIDO passkeys. Their BIO version has the ability to use a fingerprint in addition to the PIN. In the same way, your phone doesnâ€™t have to have a lock. So, either can be secure or as weak as the user chooses.

Talya (she/her):

I still, however, think a randomised password + a FIDO key is more secure, as those have the benefit of being non-phishable anyway.

I also prefer a password and 2fa, but both phone passkeys and hardware passkeys are non-phishable.

Leptopoda:

Personally I self host a password manager that stores both my password and totp.
Yes thatâ€™s not the point of 2FA but to access this account I use my master password and the yubikey making my passwords and TOTP codes secured by multiple factors.

I do something similar. I simply have a database for the passwords and another one for the TOTP backup.

Avitus:

I access my passwords nearly exclusively from my phone and I donâ€™t have time to type my tens of characters master password whenever I need to access them, so I also use biometrics with my password manager.

Agree. I do have it setup so that I need to use the full master password for the initial decryption of the password database, then fingerprint to unlock it from the background.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
CueHD:

All current Yubikeys have the ability to add an alphanumeric PIN to protect the FIDO passkeys.

I did not know that. Neat!

CueHD:

both phone passkeys and hardware passkeys are non-phishable.

Yeah I know, my point is that passkeys donâ€™t really provide any more (or any less, really) security than password+hardware key, so Iâ€™m gonna stick with that.
Despite that, I am still very much excited to see passkeys becoming a thing, as it will make the general population more secure, which is always a good thing.

CueHD:

All current Yubikeys have the ability to add an alphanumeric PIN to protect the FIDO passkeys.

The FIDO PIN is only required to be entered if the service you are logging into requires it. So far Iâ€™ve only been required to use it when the Yubikey is the only factor (passwordless).

Avitus:

Biometrics for convenience is not BS, and anyone claiming so is probably a hypocrite.

Depending on how the fingerprint is required the app might also accept the phones screen lock to be used as a fallback. Thankfully thatâ€™s not the case with my password manager but if it was it might be considered insecure (letâ€™s face it a phones screenlock probably isnâ€™t set to anything too secure/long).

CueHD:

The FIDO PIN is only required to be entered if the service you are logging into requires it.

I donâ€™t really use FIDO (only one service) but have that pin requirement for my ssh and gpg keys (very nice feature). Sorry for the offtopicnes.

Sadly you need play services to effecticely use webauthn on android. I know there are some ways yoh can achive this with microg and some other packages but I prefer my rom being vanilla (I have messed up installs with microg when updating and donâ€™t really like microg anyways).

Leptopoda:

I donâ€™t really use FIDO (only one service) but have that pin requirement for my ssh and gpg keys (very nice feature). Sorry for the offtopicnes.

The higher Yubikeys (like the one you have) have multiple features and the PINs for them are separate. So, the PIN you already set for SSH will not be the same (unless you intentionally set it that way) as for FIDO.

Another overview article on the technology:

nitrokey.com

FIDO2, WebAuthn, Passkeys in 2022 and 2023

posts.cooked:
For those of you who use KeepassXC, they just implemented support for passkeys storage!

keepassxc.org

KeePassXC 2.7.7 released â€“ KeePassXC

KeePassXC Password Manager

The passkey feature of KeepassXC works great! (KeepassXC, Linix Mint, Librewolf) The only issue Iâ€™ve found is that there is currently not a way to use the passkeys stored in a Keepass database on Android.
